AN ENULISH FARM.

The South of England contains no prettier
bay than that of Weymouth, which, with its
sheltered waters, seems like a sunny stretch
"of reaches, and sandy beaches," to delight a
steadily growing population. The bay looks
southeast, and stands out from the ridge of
South'Downs that towers along the coast for
twenty miles, forming a line of " white walls,"
such as those the Romans saw. The little
town, spread out thinly around the bay, first
gained its reputation when George III. frequented it as a health resort. He desired the
loyal townsfolk to cut a gigantic figure of a
horse and its rider on the slope of a high grasscovered hill five miles to the north, but he was
much disappointed when he saw that the head
of the well-meaning animal was turned away
from the town, instead of indicating the royal
progress towards his favorite watering-place.
Be this as it may, the figure still remains a
landmark for miles around, and an object of
interest to visitors. From the slope of the hill
a magnificent panorama may be seen. In the
foreground lies flat cultivated land, with the
picturesque town just beyond, bowed around
the bay, while, further still, Portland rears
itself on its rocky fastnesses, and seems to protect the fleet that lies in the roads below, with
its half-concealed fortress. All round stretches
the blue sea, while the bluer hemisphere above
is tinged with hazy yellow where it meets the
horizon, looking like a wondrous eye of heaven,
with golden lashes, whose blind spot—the sun
—is shining forth with all his mid-day
strength.
Just beneath our feet, and nestled in the
narrow belt of trees that separates hill from
plain, there lies a lovely farm. Its mossy
thatched roof, its little chimneys set low, and
clustered in one stack of three, and another of
two, the tiny white path cut down from the

narrow road, the outlying barns forming a
square on the south, an E-shaped cowshed
on one side, and a scrubby orchard on the
other—it is, indeed, a pretty picture.
On descending the hill we are tempted to
undo the neat little gate, and, under the pretext of some slight refreshment to inspect this
little world more closely. The path is paved
with white cobbles, the confining walls are
studded with ferns, and higher still tall hollyhocks and asters, with mignonette for borders, make two beautiful hedges. The porch
is trellised by a wild grape vine, the sour berries of which look green and dwarf. On the
doorpost hang three horseshoes, above these
are several more. The plaster on the walls inside the porch is lined with shells, apparently
collected by the children on the sea beach.
There are evidently smaller children, too, for
a half-door," or panel, is inserted in the open
doorway, to prevent their escape. The door
at the back is open, and through it may be had
a glimpse of the farm.
The kitchen and living-room seem to be on
the left, and the glories of the best room shine
out from the other side, somewhat dimly,
though, for everything is religiously covered
up. The kitchen of a farmhouse is always interesting. And this one is the more so, as it
seems to bear its age with much dignity. Like
very few, it fills the whole side of the house
from back to front. The ceiling is low, and is
supported on the thick beam that runs along its
centre. Small diamond-shaped windows open
out on the farm-yard. But the most interesting feature of the room is the splendid fireplace and chimney. How many an old hearth
is desecrated by a modern little range, with a
funny stovepipe, which seems an insult to the
wide throat of the chimney ! Here, however,
the hearth is still used. A large caldron hangs
from the chain above, and simmers gently.

An invitation to visit the farmyard is eagerly
accepted, and leaving the little ones at dinner,
we begin the tour. Hardly is the yard reached
before a fine sheep dog, whose flocks are
on the hills above, bounds out to see the visitors. He will go out in the evening to round
in the sheep, which, we are told, he often does
alone. Various hens are coming up for a
more concrete expression of favor; there is a
race from the orchard, where they have been
pecking all the morning. The old cock is trying to get through the orchard gate, so as to
share the feast—but, alas! unsuccessfully.
The cows are slowly coming in for their midday drink. llow hot it feels ! Indeed, the
dairy seems the coolest place in which we can
take refuge; it is quite small, and is filled with
a sweet fresh scent. In the half darkness not
much can be distinguished of its arrangement,
but sufficient proof of its identity is to be had
in the cold, creamy milk, with which we are
refreshed.
Sallying forth again, we reach the orchard.
The trees look quaint enough, with their odd
angles on the sloping ground, and looking over
the lower wall we see the garden, with its rows
of cabbage and potato, and the gooseberry
bushes covered with clothes that are drying in
the sun. And from this lower corner a good,
though imperfect, view of the house may be
obtained. Through the apple trees its white
walls may be traced, and the roof windows
of the upper story make wavelike ridges in
the thatch. Beyond, the hill shows hot and
parched, quivering with the rising air, and the
huge white tail of the horse seems vaguely reflected in the white flaky clouds that break the
intense blue of the sky.
Returning, we stop for a peep in the barn
opposite the house. It is dark and the highpitched roof can hardly be seen. There is one
central cross gable, and at the farther end a
stable has been cut off from the main space.
Above the stalls lies the remains of last year's
hay, to which the stifling smell is due. In one
corner there is an old-fashioned raised enclosure for theshing by hand; three dusty flails

hang on the wall. On examination two are
found to be broken, and we are told that four
years ago they were supplanted by a steam machine which can do all the threshing in two or
three days. Each complete thresher goes round
to all the farmers in turn, who share the expenses proportionately. This corner is now occupied by a chaff-cutter, and various farm
lumber.
The stables are empty, save that an old white
horse peers lazily at us, apparently weighing
the possibility of a handful of oats. Just outside there is a pig pen, which, to judge by its
appearance and odor, must be a veritable paradise for the inhabitants. They are now awaiting the arrival of"old Dan" with his pails of
kitchen refuse—it seems to them as dainty as
can be. Dan himself does not look at all dainty.
His wrinkled face, surmounted by an enormous
fiat straw hat, his shoulders bent under the
broad wooden yoke, at each end of which hangs
a pail, the old corduroy trousers tightly tied
up at the knees—he is a relic of fifty years ago,
typifying its robust hardiness as well as its ignorance. As we leave him we think of what
we owe to these faithful sons of the soil, whose
work enables us to build our fabric of learning
in the short time at our disposal, these weatherbeaten field drudges all around us.
R. L. McALL.

CONCERT AT BFtYN MAWR.

On Saturday, March ii, the musical clubs
gave their second annual concert at Bryn
Mawr. The cordial reception tendered the
clubs last season had made this year's concert
anxiously anticipated. On arriving at Bryn
Mawr a number of the members attended a tea
given for them in Pembroke East. There the
concert of the previous year was talked over,
and many of last year's men were inquired for.
The audience which greeted the clubs at Powell
Hall that evening, though not as large as last
year, was, however, very enthusiastic. Several
encores were necessary to stem the tide of enthusiasm that followed each piece. Mr. Harwood's song,"Ram-a-Jam," and his irresistible humor, made the hit of the evening, while
the quartette was obliged to sing every song in
its repertoire. In fact, all of the clubs were in
excellent form, and it was quite the universal
opinion that the concert as a whole was much
better than that of last year.
It would be hardly possible to conceive of
a more ideal location for a college than that of
Bryn Mawr. Its picturesque buildings and
extensive campus, surrounded by a country
naturally very beautiful, cannot but excite the
envy of every college man, especially Hopkinsians. Any comparison between the setting of
the two colleges must be detrimental to us,
cramped as we are in the very heart of the
city. The trip, aside from any financial consideration, was voted by the clubs to have been
the most enjoyable taken so far this year.

So, Gibbon, here it was you framed
Within the royal haunts of mind,
The story of an empire famed,
That rose supreme and then declined,
As now yon sun sinks in the lake
.Fall'n from the stars that formed its wake.
Full Fancy on broad pinions borne
Usurped a Roman eagle's flight—
Awoke the heralds of the morn,
And ruled the spirits of the night
That saw his falling eagles furled
By the late master of the world.
Old, dying Rome ! That eagle's wing
Had lost a feather here and there;
Staunch Virgil had long ceased to sing
And Gothic murmurings rent the air,
E'en where these blue-veined Gallic meres
Had borne Rome on, five hundred years.
I see you sit, whilst Mem'ry's eye
Enspirited across the flood
Reviews the days that never die
And thrills anew the coursing blood,
Till throbbing, feeling, virile heart
Beats strong within the Roman mart.
But summer lake and fragrant morn
Would argue 'peace is e'er supreme.'
How could you dream of empires torn,
Of carnage dire and war-sword's gleam,
So near the happy haunts of home,
And far across the Alps from Rome ?
I have it, my hotel now stands
Hard by this grove where once you wrote.
Your table by a change of hands
Is now become a table d'hote,
And travelers shall never find
It furnishing much food for mind.

with his peculiar drawl :

POINTS ON ATHLETICS.
V.—Jumping and Weight Throwing.

very difficult to lay down any inviolable
rules for jumping and weight-throwing, especially in regard to the make-up of the contestants. One would perhaps suppose a tall man
better fitted to go higher in the high jump than
a short man, and a heavy man better able under
all circumstances to throw a weight than a
light man. But there are so many elements
to be combined in a successful performer in
any field event that it is not wise to attempt
such generalizations.
To become proficient in either the high jump
or the broad jump, as well as in the variations
of either, one must have a certain elasticity in
the muscles of the leg, which is sometimes acquired, but is more often a natural condition.
In the broad jump this elasticity, or spring,
must be supplemented by the ability to sprint,
for when a certain height is reached in the
jump the momentum gained by the run to the
"take-off" is directly proportional to the distance that will be cleared.
When practicing for any kind of a jump, one
should be very careful to gauge the length of
the run, so that the same foot will reach the
same spot at every performance. Accuracy on
this point will insure escape from the erratic
performances so frequently seen on the athletic
field.
Putting the shot is generally conceded to
be the most difficult of all the field events, because there are so many elements essential to
success, and so many individual peculiarities
to be guarded against. There must be great
accuracy in the preliminary hop, the shoulder
and arm must do their share of the work at
just the right moment—and it takes long practice to discover which is that right moment—
and the shot must be "put" just the right
height.
Throwing the hammer is less difficult than
putting the shot, and—a point very much in
its favor as an athletic exercise—it tends to
develop the whole body, whereas the shot-putIt is

ting really strengthens the muscles on one side
only. In both these events a heavy man, who
at the same time has some agility, will usually
show to advantage, because the sixteen pounds
of solid lead or iron will not tend to lift him
off the ground, as is the case with a smaller
man, and because, of course, the more weight
one puts behind the sphere the greater will be
the force of the throw.
In throwing the discus, however, weight is
not such an essential feature. Strength, combined with accuracy, seem to be the most important elements of success, though it is hard
to name the essential points in an event which
has been so little known in modern times, especially when each individual who attempts to
master it seems to use a different method to
obtain similar result.

C. A. last Monday evening. Unfortunately,
the date was the same as that selected for the
second concert of the musical clubs. Consequently the number of those attending the reception was somewhat diminished, but the affair was, nevertheless, entirely successful.

ministers to the zesthetic desires of the musically inclined contingent of the University, was
held in McCoy Hall last Saturday evening. Selections were rendered from Mozart's The
Magic Flute, Beethoven and Mendelssohn. The
musicales have been very well received this year
and they may now be regarded as a permanent institution at Hopkins.

Within a few days a party from the University will set out on a trip to Manila for the
study of diseases common in the tropics.
Dr. Simon Flexner and Dr. S. F. Barker of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital will head the expedition. They will have as assistants Messrs. J. P.

here. The high rank which these gentlemen
hold among pathologists renders it probable

in Colgate University and lecturer at the Harvard University Summer School of Theology.

as a most successful one. It is a matter for
regret that the student body is not more fully
represented at such lectures as these, where the
character and attainments of the lecturer promise so much. Dr. Clarke is a clear and forcible
speaker, and spoke in an interesting manner on

AN ENULISH FARM.

The South of England contains no prettier
bay than that of Weymouth, which, with its
sheltered waters, seems like a sunny stretch
"of reaches, and sandy beaches," to delight a
steadily growing population. The bay looks
southeast, and stands out from the ridge of
South'Downs that towers along the coast for
twenty miles, forming a line of " white walls,"
such as those the Romans saw. The little
town, spread out thinly around the bay, first
gained its reputation when George III. frequented it as a health resort. He desired the
loyal townsfolk to cut a gigantic figure of a
horse and its rider on the slope of a high grasscovered hill five miles to the north, but he was
much disappointed when he saw that the head
of the well-meaning animal was turned away
from the town, instead of indicating the royal
progress towards his favorite watering-place.
Be this as it may, the figure still remains a
landmark for miles around, and an object of
interest to visitors. From the slope of the hill
a magnificent panorama may be seen. In the
foreground lies flat cultivated land, with the
picturesque town just beyond, bowed around
the bay, while, further still, Portland rears
itself on its rocky fastnesses, and seems to protect the fleet that lies in the roads below, with
its half-concealed fortress. All round stretches
the blue sea, while the bluer hemisphere above
is tinged with hazy yellow where it meets the
horizon, looking like a wondrous eye of heaven,
with golden lashes, whose blind spot—the sun
—is shining forth with all his mid-day
strength.
Just beneath our feet, and nestled in the
narrow belt of trees that separates hill from
plain, there lies a lovely farm. Its mossy
thatched roof, its little chimneys set low, and
clustered in one stack of three, and another of
two, the tiny white path cut down from the

No. 12

narrow road, the outlying barns forming a
square on the south, an E-shaped cowshed
on one side, and a scrubby orchard on the
other—it is, indeed, a pretty picture.
On descending the hill we are tempted to
undo the neat little gate, and, under the pretext of some slight refreshment to inspect this
little world more closely. The path is paved
with white cobbles, the confining walls are
studded with ferns, and higher still tall hollyhocks and asters, with mignonette for borders, make two beautiful hedges. The porch
is trellised by a wild grape vine, the sour berries of which look green and dwarf. On the
doorpost hang three horseshoes, above these
are several more. The plaster on the walls inside the porch is lined with shells, apparently
collected by the children on the sea beach.
There are evidently smaller children, too, for
a half-door," or panel, is inserted in the open
doorway, to prevent their escape. The door
at the back is open, and through it may be had
a glimpse of the farm.
The kitchen and living-room seem to be on
the left, and the glories of the best room shine
out from the other side, somewhat dimly,
though, for everything is religiously covered
up. The kitchen of a farmhouse is always interesting. And this one is the more so, as it
seems to bear its age with much dignity. Like
very few, it fills the whole side of the house
from back to front. The ceiling is low, and is
supported on the thick beam that runs along its
centre. Small diamond-shaped windows open
out on the farm-yard. But the most interesting feature of the room is the splendid fireplace and chimney. How many an old hearth
is desecrated by a modern little range, with a
funny stovepipe, which seems an insult to the
wide throat of the chimney ! Here, however,
the hearth is still used. A large caldron hangs
from the chain above, and simmers gently.

An invitation to visit the farmyard is eagerly
accepted, and leaving the little ones at dinner,
we begin the tour. Hardly is the yard reached
before a fine sheep dog, whose flocks are
on the hills above, bounds out to see the visitors. He will go out in the evening to round
in the sheep, which, we are told, he often does
alone. Various hens are coming up for a
more concrete expression of favor; there is a
race from the orchard, where they have been
pecking all the morning. The old cock is trying to get through the orchard gate, so as to
share the feast—but, alas! unsuccessfully.
The cows are slowly coming in for their midday drink. llow hot it feels ! Indeed, the
dairy seems the coolest place in which we can
take refuge; it is quite small, and is filled with
a sweet fresh scent. In the half darkness not
much can be distinguished of its arrangement,
but sufficient proof of its identity is to be had
in the cold, creamy milk, with which we are
refreshed.
Sallying forth again, we reach the orchard.
The trees look quaint enough, with their odd
angles on the sloping ground, and looking over
the lower wall we see the garden, with its rows
of cabbage and potato, and the gooseberry
bushes covered with clothes that are drying in
the sun. And from this lower corner a good,
though imperfect, view of the house may be
obtained. Through the apple trees its white
walls may be traced, and the roof windows
of the upper story make wavelike ridges in
the thatch. Beyond, the hill shows hot and
parched, quivering with the rising air, and the
huge white tail of the horse seems vaguely reflected in the white flaky clouds that break the
intense blue of the sky.
Returning, we stop for a peep in the barn
opposite the house. It is dark and the highpitched roof can hardly be seen. There is one
central cross gable, and at the farther end a
stable has been cut off from the main space.
Above the stalls lies the remains of last year's
hay, to which the stifling smell is due. In one
corner there is an old-fashioned raised enclosure for theshing by hand; three dusty flails

hang on the wall. On examination two are
found to be broken, and we are told that four
years ago they were supplanted by a steam machine which can do all the threshing in two or
three days. Each complete thresher goes round
to all the farmers in turn, who share the expenses proportionately. This corner is now occupied by a chaff-cutter, and various farm
lumber.
The stables are empty, save that an old white
horse peers lazily at us, apparently weighing
the possibility of a handful of oats. Just outside there is a pig pen, which, to judge by its
appearance and odor, must be a veritable paradise for the inhabitants. They are now awaiting the arrival of"old Dan" with his pails of
kitchen refuse—it seems to them as dainty as
can be. Dan himself does not look at all dainty.
His wrinkled face, surmounted by an enormous
fiat straw hat, his shoulders bent under the
broad wooden yoke, at each end of which hangs
a pail, the old corduroy trousers tightly tied
up at the knees—he is a relic of fifty years ago,
typifying its robust hardiness as well as its ignorance. As we leave him we think of what
we owe to these faithful sons of the soil, whose
work enables us to build our fabric of learning
in the short time at our disposal, these weatherbeaten field drudges all around us.

On Saturday, March ii, the musical clubs
gave their second annual concert at Bryn

clubs last season had made this year's concert
anxiously anticipated. On arriving at Bryn

concert of the previous year was talked over,

its repertoire. In fact, all of the clubs were in
excellent form, and it was quite the universal
opinion that the concert as a whole was much
better than that of last year.

a more ideal location for a college than that of
Bryn Mawr. Its picturesque buildings and
extensive campus, surrounded by a country
naturally very beautiful, cannot but excite the
envy of every college man, especially Hopkinsians. Any comparison between the setting of
the two colleges must be detrimental to us,
cramped as we are in the very heart of the
city. The trip, aside from any financial consideration, was voted by the clubs to have been
the most enjoyable taken so far this year.

POINTS ON ATHLETICS.
V.—Jumping and Weight Throwing.

very difficult to lay down any inviolable
rules for jumping and weight-throwing, especially in regard to the make-up of the contestants. One would perhaps suppose a tall man
better fitted to go higher in the high jump than
a short man, and a heavy man better able under
all circumstances to throw a weight than a
light man. But there are so many elements
to be combined in a successful performer in
any field event that it is not wise to attempt
such generalizations.
To become proficient in either the high jump
or the broad jump, as well as in the variations
of either, one must have a certain elasticity in
the muscles of the leg, which is sometimes acquired, but is more often a natural condition.
In the broad jump this elasticity, or spring,
must be supplemented by the ability to sprint,
for when a certain height is reached in the
jump the momentum gained by the run to the
"take-off" is directly proportional to the distance that will be cleared.
When practicing for any kind of a jump, one
should be very careful to gauge the length of
the run, so that the same foot will reach the
same spot at every performance. Accuracy on
this point will insure escape from the erratic
performances so frequently seen on the athletic
field.
Putting the shot is generally conceded to
be the most difficult of all the field events, because there are so many elements essential to
success, and so many individual peculiarities
to be guarded against. There must be great
accuracy in the preliminary hop, the shoulder
and arm must do their share of the work at
just the right moment—and it takes long practice to discover which is that right moment—
and the shot must be "put" just the right
height.
Throwing the hammer is less difficult than
putting the shot, and—a point very much in
its favor as an athletic exercise—it tends to
develop the whole body, whereas the shot-putIt is

ting really strengthens the muscles on one side
only. In both these events a heavy man, who
at the same time has some agility, will usually
show to advantage, because the sixteen pounds
of solid lead or iron will not tend to lift him
off the ground, as is the case with a smaller
man, and because, of course, the more weight
one puts behind the sphere the greater will be
the force of the throw.
In throwing the discus, however, weight is
not such an essential feature. Strength, combined with accuracy, seem to be the most important elements of success, though it is hard
to name the essential points in an event which
has been so little known in modern times, especially when each individual who attempts to
master it seems to use a different method to
obtain similar result.
ROBERT GARRETT.
